content.raw:
We still think that 10.0 Nms/rad is not a realistic value for joint damping and it is should be closer to 0.1 Nms/rad. 

The effective joint damping is usually quite low on a force controlled robot when the force loop is closed, because the force measured at the joint (either using a force sensor or a spring deflection) and is controlled by a feedback loop. 
The inherent damping and inertia of the actuator affect bandwidth, but not the joint torque. We have measured values of joint damping on our actuators when the force loop is closed much closer to the original 0.1 Nms/rad.

If the effort returned by the atlas_state is the effort measured at the joint (after the damping of the actuator and reduction), then we would be able to close the force loop on our side, however the set and returned effort seem to be same.

Inverting the damping using the measured velocity is hard because the velocity signals are poor.

Order of magnitude is usually a good guess, but the difference between 10 Nms/rad and  5Nms/rad is enormous for controller performance. We would prefer values measured by BDI with a closed force control loop.
